Description: Corroded iron item in the shape of a slightly curved cylindrical bar, twisted or threaded, tapering towards the extremities ending by a large button in the shape of an oblate sphere. It might be interpeted as the mouthpiece of a bridle-bit, though a little oversized, which might allow room for shanks on both sides.
Curator's comments: One of the "horses' bits" which "are sometimes bars which have had loops of cord or leather at the ends, as in fig. 1", mentioned by W.M.F. Petrie, Tanis ii, Nebesheh and Defenneh, p. 77 § 77, p. 110. Other items from Tell Dafana considered as bridle-bits: London, BM, EA 23967 (op. cit., p. 77 § 77, p. 110, pl. xxxvii, 2), Cairo, EM, JE 27378 (lost), Boston, MFA 87.515 (op. cit., p. 77 § 77). Interpretation of London, BM, EA 23965, 23966 and Boston, MFA, 87.516 (op. cit., p. 77 § 77, p. 110, pl. xxxvii, 5, 5a, 6), as well as London, BM, EA 23981, is more questionable.
Bibliographic references: Petrie 1888 / Tanis. Part II. Nebesheh (Am) and Defenneh (Tahpanhes) (p. 77 § 77, p. 110, pl. xxxvii, 1)
Leclère and Spencer 2014 / Tell Dafana Reconsidered: The Archaeology of an Egyptian Frontier Town (p.47, p.78-79, p.185, pl.27)
Condition: Corroded, broken in tweo pieces reunited
